dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man conducting Beethoven.  Air raid in progress.  Bombs falling nearby.  The orchestra continues to play.  Sudden the lights go out.  The music stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beam from a torch, bouncing, making shadows.  An  ATTENDANT, carrying the torch, hurries down the corridor. The air raid continues. He comes to a door, knocks, opens it and looks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (agitated) Dr. FurtwГ¤ngler, the Reichsminister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of heavy footsteps approaching.  The attendant  turns his torch to light the way for three men in Nazi  uniform, also with attendants and torches, marching down  the corridor. The attendant bows deeply as the REICHSMINISTER and his  aide go through the door. The other man remains in the  corridor on guard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candles light the room where the conductor shakes hands  with the Reichsminister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. FurtwГ¤ngler, I want to apologise  personally for this power failure.   I was so enjoying the performance.   In times like these we need  spiritual nourishment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bomb explodes nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I welcome this unexpected  opportunity of talking to you. (with great care) When you came on to the platform  tonight, I thought you weren't  well.  You looked tired, (a warning) Get away from this bombing. Away from the war.  Yes, you look  tired... (a crooked smile) Even in this light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark.  ON A SCREEN: scenes from Leni Riefenstahl's triump of the will. Over this:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at them. Men, women, kids.  Boy, did they love him. You see,  Steve, Adolf Hitler touched  something deep, real deep and savage  and barbaric, and it won't just go  away overnight. It's got to be  rooted out. You know what I think?  I think they were all Nazis. And  let's face it, their leaders, those  bastards now on trial in Nuremberg,  couldn't have done it alone. It's  these people, they gave all the  help that was needed. Willingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The film changes with a scratchy music soundtrack - Wagne SHOTS of high-ranking Nazis in an audience including Jose Goebbels, listening. And they're listening to and watchin Wilhelm FurtwГ¤ngler conducting. At the appropriate momen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's him.  FurtwГ¤ngler. Wilhelm  FurtwГ¤ngler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Nazis applaud. Goebbels shakes hands with FurtwГ¤ngle The film ends.  Sitting in the ruined cinema are two men: GENERAL WALLACE with files on the table, and, beside him, MAJOR STEVE  ARNOLD. A PROJECTIONIST is standing in the door of the  projection room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, you never heard of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know who Arturo Toscanini  is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's as big as Toscanini, maybe  even bigger. In this neck of the  woods, he's probably Bob Hope and  Betty Grable rolled into one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeez, and I never heard of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace glances at the file.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were in insurance before the  war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Claims assessor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conscientious, determined, dogged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amused) They said I was dogged?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they say here that when you  went on a case, you stayed on it. (looks up at Steve.) Now we can't take every Nazi in  this country to trial, although I  would like to; it's an  impossibility. So we're going for  the big boys in industry, education,  law, culture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like this bandleader.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a smile) Well, he's more than just a  bandleader, Steve. He's a great  conductor, a gifted artist. But we  believe that he sold himself to  the devil. Your number one priority  from this moment on is to connect  him to the Nazi Party. Don't be  impressed by him. I want the folks  back home to understand why we  fought this war. Find Wilhelm  FurtwГ¤ngler guilty. He represents  everything that was rotten in  Germany.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve wants to rise, but Wallace puts a hand on his shoul to make him sit again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay put, Steve. There is some  other stuff that I'd like for you  to see here. Background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods to the projectionist, then starts to go, but stop

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, one thing that may be a problem.  Our Occupation Authorities in  Wiesbaden have a duty to help these  poor unfortunates with their  defence. They keep repeating: 'We  must be just, we must be seen to  be just.' Well, I've only one thing  to say to the liberals in Wiesbaden:  fuck 'em. (as he goes) You answer to no one but me. Is  that understood? (to the projectionist  in the door) Show him the film.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Roll it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wallace goes. The projectionist starts the next reel. ON THE SCREEN: a Berlin sequence. Bombs falling. Ruins, a city devastated, empty. Flags of the four allied nations. Posters of Truman, Stalin, Churchill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is the hand that dropped the  bombs on defenceless Rotterdam,  Brussels, Belgrade. That is the  hand that destroyed the cities,  villages and homes of Russia. That  is the hand that held the whip  over the Polish, Yugoslav, French  and Norwegian slaves. That is the  hand that took their food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve watches expressionless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next reel, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE SCREEN: SHOTS of camp survivors. Then SHOTS of  emaciated corpses being bulldozed into mass graves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanitary conditions were so  appalling that heavy equipment had  to be brought in to speed the work  of cleaning up. This was Bergen  Belsen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moment this appears, Steve rises and goes quickly.  ON THE SCREEN: piles of cadavers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve having a nightmare, twisting, turning, moaning. He  wakes with a cry. He is sweating. He turns on the light,  looks at a clock, reaches for a cigarette, lights it. He  smokes. He stares at the ceiling. Later: Early morning. Cold. Steve is at the basin in his small  room, shaving. A radio on a shelf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember, men, no fraternisation.  In a German town, if you bow to a  pretty girl or pat a blond child,  you bow to all that Hitler stood  for. You bow to his reign of blood.   You caress the ideology that meant  death and destruction. You never  know who was a member of the Nazi  Party. Don't be fooled. Don't  fraternise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve's car swerves round the corner and comes to a halt. A small crowd watch workmen on ladders hammering away at stone swastika above the portico. American soldiers  supervise. Steve gets out of the car, carrying an attache case, and he, too, watches as the stone swastika falls an crashes into pieces on the road. One or two people clap,  most just stare.   The American soldiers immediately hoist the Stars and  Stripes. Steve goes into the building. The sentry salutes The driver of the car goes to the trunk and takes out a  labelled duffel bag, cans of film, a case which holds a 1 mm projector. A small BOY sidles up to him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cigarettes, chewing gum?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve and Sergeant Adams ascending a grand, winding but  damaged staircase to the rear of a spacious entrance hall A once impressive building. Signs of bomb damage everywhe German workmen doing repairs. American military personnel coming and going, saluting Steve, who barely acknowledges them. They reach the landing. Adams opens double doors and they go through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're gonna have the heating fixed  by tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few gilt chairs, a workman trying to repair the stove.  Adams opens another door for Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EMMI is hanging the standard photograph of President Trum on the wall. She turns to see Steve and Adams and is cove with confusion. She gives Steve a little curtsey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FrГ¤ulein, this is Major Arnold.  Sir, this is your secretary,  FrГ¤ulein Emmi Straube. Her file's  on your desk. They sent her over  from Admin. I'll leave you to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes. Steve scrutinises Emmi. She's embarrassed, keeps her eyes downcast. Steve goes to his desk, opens a file,  reads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You live here, in Berlin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do shorthand and typing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods, goes on reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, let's see. How long were you  in the camp for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Says here because of your father.  What's that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father was one of the officers  in the plot against Hitler. They  arrested the plotters and their  families.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your mother, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. She suffered longer. She was  in Ravensbruck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And your father was executed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods, keeps her eyes averted. He smiles sympathetical

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna call you Emmi, you're  gonna call me Steve. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a list of stuff here I'd  like you to get for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He searches his pockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you need anything, let me know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There have been messages for you. (She consults the  pad.) A Lieutenant David Wills called  from the Allied Kommandatura  Cultural Affairs office in  Wiesbaden. I don't know who he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve starts to unpack his attache case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then there have been three calls  from Dr. FurtwГ¤ngler wanting to  know when you wish to see him. I  did not speak to him personally...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands Steve a typewritten sheet. He ignores it, finds a list which he hands to her. He waits for her to read,  then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think you can get me any of that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleased) Oh yes, Major, I have recordings  of all his symphonies. I kept them  safe during the bombing. My  favourite is the Seventh Symphony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mine's the Eleventh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled) But... he only wrote nine, Major.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm kidding, Emmi. What about a  record player? You have that, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Ours was damaged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surveys the room) What's in those files?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The names of the members of the  Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra since  1934 together with their  questionnaires.  Major, what am I  to tell Dr. FurtwГ¤ngler?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell him nothing, Emmi. If he  calls again, you say you know  nothing. We're gonna keep him  waiting while I get acquainted  with his case and with the  witnesses. And, God help me, with  Beethoven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles. She tries to smile back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freezing weather. A narrow street, crowded, busy, noisy.  Some makeshift stalls set out, trestle tables, open  suitcases, people buying and selling every imaginable  commodity.   Emmi wanders through the crowd, passing a violinist, Helm Rode, wrapped up against the cold, playing Handel's Air o a G String, a bowl for money at his feet. A passer-by dro a cigarette butt in it.  Immediately, Rode retrieves the  butt. Emmi comes to a stall selling piles of gramophone records She asks the stallholder a question. He points to another stall across the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve at his desk, paging through files. A knock on the  door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant DAVID WILLS, aged twenty-four, enters, comes t Steve's desk, stands to attention, salutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Wills reporting to Major  Arnold. Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Chrissakes I hate that shit,  cut it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Steve. What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David. David Wills. I'm your liaison  officer with the Allied Kommandatura  Cultural Affairs Committee. Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds a lot of run. (studies David.) So they sent the big guns to check  up on me. We recruiting children  now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles') I guess so, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You call me sir again and I'll  make you listen to Beethoven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David half-smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you from, David?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: was born here, in Leipzig. I escaped  in '36. My parents, they sent me  to my uncle in Philadelphia. They  were to follow. But they delayed  and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breaks off. Nothing from Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our family name was Weill. But  that doesn't sound well in English.  My uncle changed it to Wills and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens and Emmi enters carrying a record player,  sees David and starts to back out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in, Emmi, this is your office,  too. Emmi, this is Lieutenant David  Wills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They nod briefly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is here to watch over us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flick from Emmi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess you admire musicians.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't. This is like a criminal  investigation, David. Musicians,  morticians, doctors, lawyers,  butchers, clerks. They're all the  same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Emmi's benefit too. She becomes still, listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a duty, a moral duty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David takes a few files, sits and starts to look through  them. Steve returns to his files. Emmi, by now, has put o a record and starts to play it: the opening of Beethoven' Fifth Symphony blasts out. The two men look up, startled. Emmi beams:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It works!  Hallelujah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmi at the door. Steve at his desk. David present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herr Rudolf Werner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WERNER enters, bows to Steve and David. Emmi goes to her  desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit down, Werner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indicates the upright chair; Werner sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to understand why you're  here. This is an investigation  into Wilhelm FurtwГ¤ngler, former  Prussian Privy Councillor, banned  from public life under Control  Council Directive No 24 and who's  applied to come before the Tribunal  of Artists of the Denazification  Commission. I'm interested in what  he was up to from 1933 to the end  of the war, understood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Werner nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rudolf Otto Werner. Wind section  since 1936. What instrument did  you play?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First oboe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have your questionnaire here. It  says you were never a member of  the Nazi Party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long silence; Steve watches him. Werner is made more  anxious. At last, in a rush:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I was never a Nazi, I have no  interest in politics, I'm a musician -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, hey, slow up, Fraulein Straube  has to take down what you say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Werner swivels round to look at Emmi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Straube? Any relation to Colonel  Joachim Straube?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a great honour to meet you,  Fraulein. Your father was a great  patriot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brief silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. FurtwГ¤ngler is a great musician.  He actively opposed the Nazis and  later on he helped many Jews to  escape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then how do you explain him being  made a Prussian Privy Councillor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was Hermann Goering. I was told  he just made the maestro his Privy  Councillor, no questions asked.  Although Dr. FurtwГ¤ngler stood up  to him. And to Dr. Goebbels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He also conducted for Hitler, didn't  he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, that's true, but he refused  to give the Nazi salute. He kept  his baton in his right hand. In  Hitler's presence. That was a brave  act...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brave?  To celebrate Hitler's  birthday with some heroic piece by  Wagner but without the Nazi salute?  Bravo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was Beethoven's Ninth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you really think it was brave?  Didn't he bow to him and shake his  hand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another man, SCHLEE, is in the chair. Only Steve and Emmi now. Pale, yellow electric light. Silence. Schlee, too, i very nervous. At last:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no, I give you my word. I  was never a member of the Nazi  Party. Never. I am in the percussion  section. I play the timpani.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve just stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, they would never have  allowed it. My brother was married  to a Jewess, may she rest in peace.  And Goebbels said... (to Emmi) ...please take this down carefully,  because it's most important,  Fraulein?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Straube.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (acting surprised) Straube? Are you by any chance  related to Colonel Joachim Straube?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was... he was a great hero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goebbels, yes, Josef Goebbels said,  'There's not a single filthy Jew  left in Germany on whose behalf  Dr. FurtwГ¤ngler has not intervened.'  No, no one could have been less of  a Nazi than Dr. FurtwГ¤ngler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this was the same guy who  conducted for Adolf on his birthday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was forced to do that. But he  refused to give the Nazi salute in  front of Hitler. He kept his baton  in his hand, you can't salute with  a baton in your hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what about the Nuremberg Rally?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, we...we played on the evening  before the Rally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (straight-faced) Oh! The evening before, I see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Dr. FurtwГ¤ngler was absolutely  clear about this: politics and art  must be kept separate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Politics and art must be kept  separate. I'll remember that. But  let me see if you can help me with  something I just don't understand.  I'd really like to know why all  you guys are so crazy about him.  What's his secret?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schlee tries to find words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's hard to explain. I can  only tell you from my own  experience. Soon after I joined  the orchestra, we were rehearsing  the Third Symphony of Beethoven,  the Eroica. There are several rather  difficult passages for the timpani.  One particular crescendo. During  the break, I asked how he wanted  it played. He was studying his  score. He didn't look up. He said,  'Just watch me.'  So, of course, I  did. I never stopped watching him.  The moment came. And suddenly, he  turned to me and our eyes were  locked. There was something in his  look that...  that simply demanded  the crescendo. I shall never forget  his look. It was a moment of... of  magic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve nods, thinks for a moment. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever seen Adolf Hitler's eyes  when he was making a speech? I've  seen 'em on films.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was looking at FurtwГ¤ngler like  that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you mean, Major.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you got to the crescendo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schlee looks at him bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the back, David and Steve. Military driver. The car's  making its way along a road that skirts a lake towards a  grand mansion from which fly the four Allied flags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think a whole orchestra, what,  a hundred and forty or so guys,  could be orchestrated?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess it's possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what does the Russki want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Dymshitz asked specially  to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Dim-shits'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge, cavernous room, once the ballroom.   In the centre, a table with four chairs. To one side,  antique furniture, objets d'art, paintings. Four Allied  officers are surveying the treasures: COLONEL DYMSHITZ,  COLONEL GREEN (American), MAJOR RICHARDS (British) and  CAPTAIN VERNAY (French). What they say is barely audible, low mumbles. They're accompanied by aides with clipboards taking notes. Beyond, and some distance away, a row of gilt chairs for  observers where David and Steve take their seats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are they doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispered) They're trying to sort out some of  the works of art the Nazis stole  from occupied territories. Who  really owns what? That's Colonel  Dymshitz, on the far side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dymshitz, small, intelligent face, cunning eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: art historian, head of the famous  Leningrad Museum of Art. He is an  expert on German culture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Green, correct, formal, precise, immaculate. Richards,  bespectacled and nondescript. Vernay, upright, proud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly raising  his voice) Je suis navrГ©, Colonel, cette  peinture n'est pas la propriГ©tГ© de  I'union soviГ©tique mats bien cette  de la France.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he saying? Henri, what is  you saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's saying that picture is the  property of France

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'est un Braque qui avec Picasso  Г©tait un des pionniers du cubisme.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in French) I know who Georges Braque is,  Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost  simultaneously) It's a Barque.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can produce the provenance of  this Braque, you say provenance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside the club room for the participants. Buzz of  conversation, clink of glasses, cups. The terrace is  deserted. A waiter carries a tray with various refreshments to a  quiet corner where Dymshitz, Green, Vernay, his aide  LIEUTENANT SIMON, Steve and David sit in comfortable  armchairs. The waiter serves them. During this:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Major, my name is Dymshitz.  I'm glad to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel. Pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Major, tell me, have you  questioned Dr. FurtwГ¤ngler?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've had two meetings with him.  He's a great musician. Maybe the  greatest conductor in the world.  His Brahms, Beethoven, Schubert -  unequalled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve makes a non-committal gesture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll come straight to point. I've  offered him a very attractive  position. Conductor of the  Staatsoper Unten den Linden. He  refused. But I want him. I want  him badly. And I want your help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, just a moment, you should  have discussed this with me first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm discussing it with you now.  Major, I want you to drop your  investigation, save everybody time  and trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't drop a case just like  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give you another conductor in  exchange or writer, musician, actor  what...what do you care?  But I  like FurtwГ¤ngler. He's my favourite  conductor. (chuckles.) Mine and Hitler's. He's our  favourite conductor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rode is seated, waiting. Nervous, tense. The sound of  laughter, David's laughter from the office. It makes him  even more uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmi and David laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I clicked my heels, saluted and  bowed at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He demonstrates. She laughs again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's because you had a proper  upbringing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. I was raised very  strictly. So don't speak before  you are spoken to!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! And don't wave your hands about!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Respect your elders and your  betters!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And no elbows on the table!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eating is eating... and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And talking is talking! Well, I  think we better get on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. So, this is going to be  very formal, too, now. Lieutenant  David Wills requests die pleasure  of die company of Fraulein Emmi  Straube at dinner any night she  cares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles just as Steve bursts in. He's in a bright,  cheerful, energetic mood. David draws back guiltily. Emmi, embarrassed, hesitates  then turns to the typewriter and types furiously. Seeing  this, Steve stops, but just for a brief moment. Then, as  he goes to his desk:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, need to ask you something.  You heard this rumour the British  found something called the Hinkel  Archive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The British occupy the building  where this guy, Hinkel, ran the  Nazi Ministry of Culture and it  seems they've... they've discovered  his secret archive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, but the British are  excited about it, I know that. The  rumour is Hinkel kept a file on  every artist working in the Third  Reich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeez. And you think the British'll  share it with their Allies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major Richards said he'd call to  let us know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's big of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks from David to Emmi as if trying to work out  something.  Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, better question the next  witness. I bet you a bottle of  French champagne he tells us the  baton story inside ten minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a bet. You're the witness,  Emmi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. Rode in the witness chair. Steve studying the file. David and Emmi ready to take notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helmuth Alfred Rode. Second  violinist since 1935. What's it  mean, second violinist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means I wasn't good enough to  be a first violinist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He chuckles, looks around for approval. Steve grins  encouragingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, and according to your  questionnaire, Helmuth, you never  joined the Nazi Party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? Never.  Never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I know everyone now says they  were never Nazis but in my case it  is absolutely one hundred per cent  true. I am a Catholic, it would  have been totally against my  conscience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Steve lights a cigarette; Rode eyes it hungrily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it true you're going to interview  Dr. FurtwГ¤ngler today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll ask the questions, Helmuth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Did you know that he  refused to give the Nazi salute  when Hitler was present in the  audience?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve flicks David a glance, waggles his finger like a  baton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The problem was how could he avoid  giving the Devil's salute when  Satan was actually sitting there. (modestly taps his  chest with his  thumb.) And, I said, 'Dr. FurtwГ¤ngler, why  not enter with the baton in your  right hand? Hitler will be sitting  in the front row. If you give the  salute with the baton in your right  hand it'll look like you're going  to poke his eyes out.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chuckles. David mouths I win to Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was...He was really grateful to  me for that. After the concert,  I... I stole that baton as a memento  of a great act of courage. I still  have it. I should have brought it  to show you. I hope I'm not going  too fast for you, Fraulein?-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Straube.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve and David exchange a brief look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Straube. Any relation to Colonel  Joachim Straube?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing) I am deeply honoured to be in your  presence, Fraulein Straube. Your  father was a true patriot, a man  of God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crosses himself. Silence. David raises a discreet fing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a question for Helmuth,  David?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. What was the orchestra's  reaction when they asked you to  play for Hitler's birthday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, we didn't play for his birthday,  we played the evening before - it  was the 19th of April not the 20th.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know Hans Hinkel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (alarmed) Do I know Hans Hinkel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I asked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I know Hans Hinkel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seem to understand the question,  now how about answering it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hans Hinkel was in the Ministry of  Culture; how could I know such a  man?  I

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brief silence; a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear the British have his... his  archive, files, records.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what's in this archive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could I know what's in the  archive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve nods, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, you can go now, Helmuth. Get  out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rode stands and bows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The final bars of the Fifth Symphony. Snowing. Dim light. There is more furniture now: two chairs, one comfortable, the other upright.  A sitting area by the window with the telephone extension. The 16-mm projector set up in anothe corner. Steve, at his desk, wrapped up against the cold, going  through files, making notes. He stops, seems to listen,  then goes to the window, looks out. The music ends. The record hisses. Steve just stares out  at the night and the snow. The record continues to hiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tram packed to overflowing. Then, a sudden stir among the passengers as people push through trying to find spac One of them is FURTWГ„NGLER. He's recognised. Whispering. He stares ahead or keeps his eyes downcast. An elderly ma tugs at his coat, half-rises, offering his seat.   FurtwГ¤ngler manages a smile and shakes his head. The tra rattles on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FurtwГ¤ngler approaches Adams at his desk. He crosses to the stairs. German workmen stop what they  are doing to let him pass. One of them bows. On the upper landing, Emmi is making her way to Steve's  office. She stops, sees FurtwГ¤ngler on the stairs and then dashe to Steve's door. FURTWГ„NGLER FurtwГ¤ngler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmi bursts in on Steve and David. She's overawed:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major, Major... he's here ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut the door, Emmi. Sit down,  Emmi. We're going to keep him  waiting, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmi glances out again and reluctantly closes the door,  Steve sits calmly, relaxed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmi, get us some coffee, will  you? And, Emmi, don't offer him  coffee. Don't even greet him, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FurtwГ¤ngler sits, waiting. Emmi, deeply embarrassed, hur through.. FurtwГ¤ngler is about to ask her something, but she's gone. He waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve and David preparing papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FurtwГ¤ngler waiting. Emmi enters from the landing door  carrying a tray and three mugs of coffee. She hurries  towards the office door, eyes downcast. FURTWГ„NGLER Fraulein?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmi stops. FURTWГ„NGLER How long am I to be kept waiting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmi bites her lip and, without looking at him, disappear into the office.  FurtwГ¤ngler closes his eyes, breathes  deeply. He stands, goes to the window, looks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Steve studying his notes. David watching him.  Emmi staring forlornly into space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Emmi, go get him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmi rises, opens the door, nods, turns back to Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. FurtwГ¤ngler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FurtwГ¤ngler enters. As he passes her, Emmi gives him a  small curtsey. David nods. Steve doesn't look up.   FurtwГ¤ngler waits a moment, glances round, sees the more comfortable chair and sits in it. Steve looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't hear anyone invite you to  sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FurtwГ¤ngler stands. Steve points to the other chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FurtwГ¤ngler sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to understand why you're  here. You're automatically banned  from public life under Control  Council Directive No 24. We're  here to look into your case before  you appear in front of the Tribunal  for Artists of the Denazification  Commission. You understand that? FURTWГ„NGLER I have already been cleared by a  Denazification Tribunal in Austria.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What they do in Austria doesn't  interest me one little bit. Okay?   I have your questionnaire here, (reading) Gustav Heinrich Ernst Martin Wilhelm  FurtwГ¤ngler, born Berlin, January  1886. Orchestral conductor. And  you say here you were never a member  of the Nazi Party. FURTWГ„NGLER That is correct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A very long silence. When the silence is unbearable Steve speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you tell us about being made  a Prussian Privy Councillor. How  did that happen to a non-Party  member? FURTWГ„NGLER I received a telegram from Hermann  Goering informing me that he had  made me a Privy Councillor. I was  not given the opportunity either  to accept or refuse. After the  dreadful events of November 1938,  the violent attacks on the Jews, I  stopped using the title.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Vice-President of the  Chamber of Music, you used that  title didn't you? But then I suppose  you had no choice there either,  because I suppose Dr. Goebbels  just sent you a telegram saying,  Dear Mr. Vice-President. FURTWГ„NGLER I don't think Dr. Goebbels sent me  a telegram. I was simply told. In  a letter, I believe. I don't  remember exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goebbels and Goering were sure  heaping honours on you. One makes  you a Privy Councillor, the other  makes you Vice-President of the  Chamber of Music, and you weren't  even a member of the Party, how do  you explain that? FURTWГ„NGLER Well, there was a constant battle  between Goering and Goebbels as to  which of them would control German  culture. I was simply a pawn.   Anyway, I resigned from the  Musikkammer at the same time I  resigned as Musical Director of  the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra.  In 1934.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David puts up a hand. Steve nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why was that? Why did you resign,  Dr. FurtwГ¤ngler? FURTWГ„NGLER I wrote an open letter to the  newspapers condemning what they  were doing to music, making these  distinctions between Jews and non- Jews. For my part, the only divide  in art is between good and bad.  Eventually, Goebbels summoned me  and told me I could leave the  country if I wanted to but under  no condition would I ever be allowed  to return. I always believe that  you have to fight from the inside  not from without. I asked myself,  what's the duty of an artist, to  stay or to leave? And then Goebbels  demanded that I acknowledge Hitler  as solely responsible for cultural  policy. Well, that was a fact and  it seemed pointless to deny it. I  simply acknowledged that Hitler  and the Minister of Culture  appointed by him were solely  responsible for the cultural policy  of the Reich. What I wanted to  express was that I, personally,  had no responsibility whatsoever  for their cultural policy. I have  always had the view that art and  politics should... should have  nothing to do with each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why did you conduct at one of  their Nuremberg rallies? FURTWГ„NGLER (flaring) I did not conduct at at the rally,  I conducted on the evening before  the rally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sounds like the small print  in one of our insurance policies,  Wilhelm. And what about April 19,  1942?  The eve of Hitler's fifty- third birthday, the big celebration;  you conducted for Hitler, didn't  you? Was that in keeping with your  view that art and politics have  nothing to do with each other? FURTWГ„NGLER (flustered) That... that was a different matter,  I... I was tricked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come? FURTWГ„NGLER Could I have a glass of water,  please? Please, Fraulein?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Straube.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve looks expectant but FurtwГ¤ngler remains silent. St nods to Emmi, who gets the water.  FurtwГ¤ngler drinks.  Steve waits. FURTWГ„ANGLER Thank you. I was in Vienna,  rehearsing the Ninth Symphony of  Beethoven, when Goebbels called  and said I had to conduct at  Hitler's birthday. I'd always  managed to wriggle out of such  invitations, pleading previous  engagements, illness, having my  doctors state I was not well and  so on and so on. I was also  fortunate that Baldur von Shirach,  who controlled Vienna, hated Dr.  Goebbels and would do anything to  thwart his wishes. But this time  Goebbels got to my doctors before  me; they were frightened off, and  von Schirach was threatened, bullied  and gave in. So, I had no  alternative but to conduct for  Hitler. Believe me, I knew I had  compromised, and I deeply regret  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (playing with him) Doesn't sound much of a trick to  me. Sounds like you made a deal. FURTWГ„NGLER I made no deal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't buy that. FURTWГ„NGLER It's the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Steve paces. Then suddenly turns on FurtwГ¤ngler

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I keep hearing you helped a lot of  Jews to escape. How did you do  that? FURTWГ„NGLER I don't remember in detail, there  were so many.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you call someone you knew? FURTWГ„NGLER I may have, as... as I said, I  simply don't remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me me help you, then. You picked  up the phone and made a call - (Mimes a telephone.) 'Hello, Adolf? Wilhelm speaking.  Listen, old pal, there's a Jew-boy  musician I want you to help. He  needs a permit to get to Paris.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmi sticks her fingers in her ears and shuts her eyes  tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or maybe you called Goebbels or  Goering? You were so close you  were in the same shithouse as them. FURTWГ„NGLER May I ask a question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. FURTWГ„NGLER When will my case be heard by the  Tribunal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your guess is as good as mine. FURTWГ„NGLER I need to work. I need to make my  living. I live off the generosity  of friends...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tough, tough! FURTWГ„NGLER (now more and more  agitated) Then why is it, please, that another  conductor who was actually a member  of the Party, who used to play the  Horst Wessel before his concerts,  has already been cleared and is  working again while I have to wait  and wait and wait?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, he wasn't my case.  Why did you escape to Switzerland  just before the war ended? FURTWГ„NGLER It was because I learned that the  Gestapo was about to arrest me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why were they going to arrest you? FURTWГ„NGLER I believe it was because of another  letter I'd written to Goebbels  lamenting the decline of musical  standards due to racial policies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't complain about the racial  policies, just about the musical  standards, is that right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, how did you learn that the  Gestapo was out to get you? FURTWГ„NGLER During an enforced hour-long  interval because of a power failure  at a concert here in Berlin, Albert  Speer, the Minister of Armaments,  said to me, 'You look very tired  Dr. FurtwГ¤ngler, you should go  abroad for a while.' I knew exactly  what he meant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure knew a lot of people in  high places. FURTWГ„NGLER It would be truer to say, I think,  that a lot of people in high places  knew me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were real close to all of them,  to Adolf, to Hermann, to Joseph,  to Baldur, and now Albert, (flaring) So, let's hear the truth, let's  come clean. What was your Party  number? FURTWГ„NGLER If you are going to bully me like  this, Major, you had better do  your homework. You obviously have  no idea how impertinent and stupid  your questions are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve is stung. His eyes narrow dangerously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, you remember I said I had a  question that he wouldn't be able  to answer? Well, I'm gonna ask it  now.  You ready for this, Wilhelm?  It's a tough one. Why didn't you  get out right at the start when  Hitler came to power in 1933? Why  didn't you leave Germany?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a list of names here, people  in your profession, who got out in  '33. Bruno Walter, Otto Klemperer,  Arnold Schoenberg, Max Reinhardt... FURTWГ„NGLER They were Jews, they had to leave.  They were right to leave. (He breathes deeply,  summons strength.) I could not leave my country in  her deepest misery. After all, I  am a German.  I... I stayed in my  homeland. Is that my sin in your  eyes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, David? He can't answer the  question. I'll ask it again,  Wilhelm, and don't give me any  more airy-fairy, intellectual  bullshit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The telephone rings. No one moves. Then Emmi picks up the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major Arnold's office. Yes, he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Offers the phone to David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Major Richards for Lieutenant  Wills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David takes the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David Wills. Yes, sir. (listens.) Well, you want me to tell him?  Okay, (to Steve) Major Richards wants a word with  you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve indicates he'll take the call on the extension.   FurtwГ¤ngler stands. As Steve crosses to the extension:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (muttering) Why can't he just ask for me? Why  does he have to ask for you first?  Goddamn British, so correct!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up the extension. Emmi puts down her receiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve Arnold... FURTWГ„NGLER I've had enough of this, I'm  leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes quickly. David dashes after him. INT. WAITING ROOM - DAY FurtwГ¤ngler is at the door when  David reaches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. FurtwГ¤ngler!  Dr. FurtwГ¤ngler!  Please, please... (a warning) Don't. It's not advisable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of Steve laughing with delight.  FurtwГ¤ngler  hesitates.  Emmi comes to the waiting-room door, watches, as if on  guard. David comes round to face FurtwГ¤ngler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he gathers courage) When I was a child, my father, he  took me to... he took me to one of  your concerts. I remember you  conducted Beethoven's Fifth  Symphony. I was deeply moved. And  I've loved music ever since. I was  grateful to you. And I've admired  you. How could you... how could  you serve those criminals?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He falls silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmi, at the open door, has been listening. She's shocked turns away to see Steve, on the extension, chuckling,  grinning from ear to ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many?  Jesus, that's dynamite! Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and FurtwГ¤ngler haven't moved. Both are looking  towards Steve's office and Emmi in the doorway. Again the sound of Steve's laugh. Then Emmi steps into th room, approaches FurtwГ¤ngler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. FurtwГ¤ngler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives her a wonderful smile.  And, suddenly, Steve sta in the doorway, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well now. Aren't we all sociable?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others are made awkward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to hand it to the British,  David. You know what those guys  are?  Decent. (He sits, crosses  his legs.) Tell me, Herr Dr. FurtwГ¤ngler, do  you know Hans Hinkel? FURTWГ„NGLER Yes, a despicable human being. He  was in the Ministry of Culture.  His job was to get rid of Jews in  the arts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup, that's him, that's the guy.  You know what else the little creep  did? He kept files, close on 250,000  files. And you know what's in those  files? FURTWГ„NGLER Certainly not, but I knew he had  informers everywhere. Even in my  orchestra there was someone

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? FURTWГ„NGLER I wasn't told. I just knew it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How? FURTWГ„NGLER (uneasy) I was warned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who warned you?  FURTWГ„NGLER (lowering his head) Goering. Because Hinkel was working  for Goebbels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did Goering say? FURTWГ„NGLER He told me to be careful as one of  Goebbels' men was watching me. He  read a report on me - everything I  said was quoted word by word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh boy, you're gonna love this.  Take your time with this now. Those  files contain the details of every  working artist in this country.  Those files are gonna tell us who  joined the Party, who informed and  who was helpful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FurtwГ¤ngler goes to the door. David opens it for him.  FurtwГ¤ngler nods, then turns to Emmi, bows to her and  smiles. He goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your name, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David Wills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a long trestle table running the length of the  room, with chairs, as if in a library. A notice requests  'Silence'. British and American servicemen, a Russian and a French  officer studying papers, making notes. At the furthest  end, Steve, David and Emmi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fantastic! The only condition is  we have to do the work here. I  want you to collect all the files  on the boys in the band.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David discovers that the archive room was originally a  synagogue. He is moved. He lays stones on the rail of wha was once the ark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmi and David surrounded by files, sifting through, maki notes. They examine the Hinkel Archive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another day. Sunshine pouring in. Steve seated as before, but Emmi and David again in different places. Emmi rises, goes to Steve, shows him something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you can have a look at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He reads. He is not pleased. He writes furiously. Emmi  returns to her place. Suddenly, a movement causes Steve t look up. STEVE AND HIS POV: David slides a note across to Emmi.  Emmi reads the note. David watches her. She looks at him. She almost smiles, nods surreptitiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a whisper) Schubert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She feels Steve's eyes on her, and returns quickly to her work. Steve is displeased and even more suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Summer evening. The first movement of Schubert's String  Quintet in C Major, D956, played by three men and two wom to a large audience packed into the ruins, partly open to the sky, Dymshitz  among them. At the rear of the church, Emmi and David, enraptured,  seated side by side. The first movement ends and the Adagio begins. After the  music gathers momentum: Rain. Thunder and lightning. The musicians continue to  play, unperturbed.  They are coming to the end of the  Quintet. David and Emmi huddled together. Some umbrellas up and  then movement which catches David's attention. He nudges  Emmi, I indicates with his chin. People have moved to reveal FurtwГ¤ngler: seated, wearing hat, still I' as a statue, soaked, listening,  expressionless. Much applause. The musicians bow. The audience start to  leave. Emmi and David emerge from the ruins.  FurtwГ¤ngler passe them. They nod awkwardly. He doesn't respond but is about to  walk on when Dymshitz pushes through, nods to David, who  salutes. Dymshitz catches up with FurtwГ¤ngler. They are  near to Emmi and David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. FurtwГ¤ngler -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FurtwГ¤ngler stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moving, you agree? Whenever I hear  Schubert I am moved.  You agree? FURTWГ„NGLER The tempi were a little too correct  for my taste. But I expect that is  because of the rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods politely, is about to go -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (also for David's  benefit) Wait, Doctor, I understand you  have difficulties with the  Americans. I want you to know, I  am your champion. We can help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FurtwГ¤ngler allows himself a faint smile, tips his hat,  and then hurries off into the night. Dymshitz goes, too. David and Emmi watch them.  Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frowning, worried) What does he mean, too correct?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huddled under their umbrella, they dash off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve, fully dressed, lies on the bed in his small, shabb room, staring into space. He is suddenly startled by a  loud roll of thunder and then a fierce crack of lightning He goes to the window, watching the rain. He stands  motionless for a second, then makes a decision. He grabs  his cap, a raincoat from the back of the door. Another  loud thunderclap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dancers jitterbugging and jiving. Among them, David and  Emmi also dancing, imitating the others and having a good time. The music ends. Scattered applause. The band leaves the platform. The dancers return to tables or the bar.   Later: David and Emmi at their table, eating. She eats voracious eyes glazed, all her concentration on the food in front o her. David is fascinated, can't stop watching her. Steve enters the club, makes his way to the bar, orders a drink. Steve turns to survey the room, almost at once spots Davi and Emmi, their backs to him. He observes them. David and Emmi at their table: They have finished their  meal. Emmi is silent now, staring at her empty plate.  Steve is suddenly at their table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what is this, the office  party?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Emmi are frozen with embarrassment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I join you? (sits down, beams.) So, what have you two been up to  tonight? Hey. Don't I owe you a  bottle of French champagne?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tries to get a waiter's attention but fails. В• No respon

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, David, you're a lucky  guy. I invited Emmi here but she  turned me down. You must've hidden  depths, David...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: he band starts to play; he stands, holds out a hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Emmi, let's dance. I'll  teach you how to jive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is horribly embarrassed, doesn't move. David suddenly stands and takes Emmi by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very sorry, Major, but I  promised her mother, we have to  go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They leave quickly. Steve watches them. He sinks down, angry and jealous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Emmi enter the hall, each locked in their own  thoughts.  They reach the foot of the stairs and pause.   They want to kiss but both are too awkward. She starts up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't see me to my door, there's  no need.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I promised your mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops, turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sleep well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She continues on her way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve and Emmi at work on the files. One or two BRITISH  OFFICERS present, and David, who is working at the far en of the table. He has a cold. Emmi, who also has a cold, opens a file and is immediatel alert. She reads. She blows her nose. She is uncertain.  She looks up at Steve. She makes a decision. She rises,  takes the file to Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Major. I found this on  Helmuth Rode. You remember? The  second violinist? Look, he's  Austrian not German. But it's this  that's more important, I think...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She points to something. Steve laughs loudly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sssh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David looks up at them, puzzled. Then a British SERGEANT  comes into the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Wills, telephone -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David rises and as he goes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exasperated) What is this, a railway station?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a booth near the front desk, David is on the telephone

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into telephone) David. Wills. Hello? Who? Who in  Wiesbaden?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irritated, he taps the receiver but the line's gone dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve lies, shirt off, taking the sun. Children playing.  Noise behind him of someone in the bushes. Steve doesn't  move. Rode, carrying a slender leather case, pushes through to  Steve, who remains with his eyes closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyes still closed) Helmuth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess what I am holding in my hand.  You like guessing games?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love 'em, Helmuth. I give up. What  are you holding in your hand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rode takes from the case a conductor's baton. Steve opens one eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Dr. FurtwГ¤ngler's baton, which  I stole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one he kept in his right hand.   Yes, you remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could I forget?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sits up, takes the baton. Somewhere a child laughs; sudde Steve thrusts the baton at Rode.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, show me, I want to see you  do it. Pretend I'm Adolf. You're  the maestro, and you have the baton  in your right hand, but you give  me the salute just the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not here, Major, there are people,  if anybody should see... please,  please, Major...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do it, Helmuth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After nervous looks over his shoulder Rode, salutes half- heartedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do it right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rode thrusts his hand out in the Nazi salute.  People by the lake: Mostly elderly, but some younger ones see Rode saluting.  Some turn away. Others stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look great doing that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rode and Steve: Rode looks around nervously, lowers his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I see what you mean. You nearly  poked my eyes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly.  Replaces the baton, gives  Steve the case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, Helmuth, it'll be our  secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ball comes bounding towards them. Steve catches it. The a BOY runs in, looks hopeful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister, mister, here, here,  mister!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve tosses the ball back to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great catch, kid. The boy runs  off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. You wanted to see me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve pats the spot next to him and Rode sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You usually don't work on Sunday,  Major?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All in the cause of humanity,  Helmuth. Or should I call you one- zero-four-nine-three-three-one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One-zero-four-nine-three-three- one. Or d'you mind if I just call  you 'one'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rode makes an attempt to go but Steve grabs him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I say you are,  Helmuth? I say you're a piece of  shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rode suddenly starts to retch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That bastard!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People by the lakeside: Faces turning at Rode's sobs. Impassive. Blank. Steve and Rode:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's the bastard, Helmuth? Hinkel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rode nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? He promised to remove your  file?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rode vomits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what about before that? What  were you a member of in Austria?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a moment:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was a member of...?  Speak up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barely audible) I was a member of the Communist  Party. I was a communist. That's  what Hinkel had over me. He knew  everything. He held that over me.  That's how he made me co-operate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I see, he made you co-operate.  And now are you a communist again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry) You don't know what it's like to  wake up every single morning of  your life terrified, you don't  know that - (he stops.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brief silence. Steve stands. Further along the lakeside: Steve and Rode walk. People about. Boats on the lake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would never, in my wildest dreams,  have ever been a second violinist  in the Berlin Philharmonic. When  they got rid of the... the Jews in  the orchestra, it gave people like  me a chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rode rowing Steve in a small boat. Rode, exhausted, stops The boat drifts. Steve watches him for a moment, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helmuth, you ever heard of plea- bargaining?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rode, trying to catch his breath, shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk about power, I have the power  to give you work, make your life  easier. Your past won't be  mentioned. I could give you a job  tomorrow but I have to get something  in return. See, Helmuth? That's  plea-bargaining.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No response. Rode keeps his head bowed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can give you freedom of movement,  freedom to work, freedom, Helmuth.  But I need something in return.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major, we're discussing a man of  genius, I don't want...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck that, Helmuth. You want to  discuss symbols here?  This guy  was a front man. He was the piper,  but he played their tune, you get  my philosophical meaning?  I'm not  interested in small fish, I'm after  Moby Dick. Come on, Helmuth. Hard  facts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Then Rode slowly raises his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only thing I know is he's an  anti-Semite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. You, too. Like everyone  else in this goddamn country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rode and Steve walking. Rode suddenly turns to him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've remembered something else...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FurtwГ¤ngler sent Hitler a telegram  for his birthday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of your people told me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of my people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start to walk away from the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. A corporal. US Army. A Jew.  He said he'd seen the telegram in  the Chancellery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son-of-a-gun. We'll find the  corporal and we'll find the  telegram.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops, takes out a cigarette, offers one to Rode, ligh them both, gives Rode the packet.  They smoke for a momen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I need documentary proof. You  know of anything like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. But that's why we hated him.  We admired him as a conductor but  we all hated him too because he  didn't have to join the Party and  yet he had a better life than any  of us. He didn't have to go and  deliver a report after every trip  abroad. He got everything from  them, everything. He was filthier  than any of us Party members.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun is setting. Rode stops suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a rumour... I don't know  if it's true or not... but ask him  about von der Null.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never heard of him, who is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edwin von der Null. Music critic.  He gave FurtwГ¤ngler terrible reviews  while he raved about Herbert von  Karajan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Also a conductor. Very brilliant.  Young. Von der Null called him  'The Miracle von Karajan'.   FurtwГ¤ngler was outraged and they  say he had von der Null conscripted  into the army. The same thing  happened to another critic. True  or not, it's not such a bad idea.   Critics give you bad reviews, you  have them sent to the Russian front. (Chuckks.) But if you really want to get  FurtwГ¤ngler, ask him about Herbert  von Karajan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Miracle Kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, yes you may notice that he  cannot even bring himself to utter  his name, he... he refers to him  as K.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rode tries to make up his mind about something, then  decides. He reaches into an inside pocket and takes out a small black notebook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And ask him about his private life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His private life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rode hesitates, then he hands Steve the black book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it's all in here. His women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve going along the shelves filled with files. He's at  the H, then I, then J. He stops at the letter K. With his forefinger, he runs down the files. He stops, pulls out a fat file:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens the file.   INSERT: - the file: ID PHOTOGRAPHS of an energetic-looking young man and two  Nazi Party membership booklets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David makes his way from the counter. He carries a tray  with two cups of coffee. He goes to a table where CAPTAIN MARTIN sits, papers and files spread before him. David  gives him his coffee, then sits across from him, blows hi nose. Silence while they sugar and milk their coffee. David awa of Martin's eyes on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you stand on all this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On all what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On FurtwГ¤ngler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He breaks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You represent the United States  now. We have a moral duty to be  just and we have to be seen to be  just.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major Arnold believes he has a  moral duty, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our duty is to help FurtwГ¤ngler  with his defence, (carefully) That's why I want you to look at  this... (he selects papers  from the table.) These are part of the transcripts  of the trial at Nuremberg. We can't  get them translated fast enough.  But I guess you understand German,  right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passes papers across to David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the evidence of a guy named  Dahlerus. He's a Swede. Friend of  Hermann Goering. I want you to  study it. And I want you to use  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David tries to sneeze but fails; he starts to read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to find more stuff to  feed you. We'll have some other  suggestions. We need to build a  case for the defence - based not  on feelings, not on prejudice, but  on facts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He watches David read. David is engrossed. Almost  imperceptibly, he shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A half-ruined cafГ© with tables on the sidewalk. WERNER,  the timpanist, SCHLEE, the oboist, and two others seated  at one of the tables, drinking coffee.  David carries an attachГ© case and walks towards the cafГ He scans the people at the tables, sees the musicians and approaches. They stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Wills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David nods

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Herr Schlee, timpanist, Herr Romer,  cello and Herr Schmidt, viola.  They are willing to help. We have  already ordered ourselves coffee.  I hope you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole orchestra will vouch for  him. He was always there to support  us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need names, if possible with  addresses, because it's urgent.  Names of musicians saved by Dr.  FurtwГ¤ngler, people he helped to  escape abroad. Let's go somewhere  public.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David leaves money on the table and then walks off with  the four men. They talk as they make their way down a sid street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve and Dymshitz sit opposite each other and clink vodk glasses.  They have been drinking but are not yet drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To co-operation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drink. Dymshitz pours more vodka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was in Vienna. I had with me an  Austrian chauffeur, Max his name  was, he spent time in the camps.  We were looking at these Viennese  cleaning up the bomb damage,  scavenging for rotting food, butt  ends, anything. I said, 'To think  a million of these people came out  to welcome Adolf on the day he  entered the city, a million of  'em, and now look at 'em.'  And  Max said, 'Oh, not these people,  Major. These people were all at  home hiding Jews in their attics.'  You get the point, Colonel? The  point is they're all full of shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FurtwГ¤ngler's in a different  category.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're dealing with degenerates  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is still for a moment, then grabs the bottle and pours himself a drink, downs it. Dymshitz watches him, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Degenerates?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: German modern paintings stacked untidily. Dymshitz, carrying a vodka bottle and his glass, shows  Steve the paintings. Steve, too, has a glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A great artist will have great  privileges in a Russian zone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why he didn't get the hell  out of here when he had the chance!  I put that to him, he couldn't  answer. Why didn't he go and direct  in America, like that Italian,  Toscanini.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dymshitz pours vodkas, raises his glass, drinks. So does  Steve. Now, their moods swing with the drink. Dymshitz drinks; then sits, sinks into his own world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lost for a moment) Perhaps... perhaps he believed he  could at least try to preserve  something important, things like  an orchestra, a school. That's his  country. Maybe he has an old mother  who can't be left alone. Maybe he  has brothers, sisters... you  can't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A forlorn look at Steve. His eyes are misty, he is visibl drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a wry smile) Colonel. He had no sisters, no  brothers, only a lot of love  affairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, Major, why should he leave  his country, his mother tongue,  his family, his history, his past,  his future, just because now,  suddenly, there is a dictatorship?  Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what... before that turns  rotten...  What if they surround  the space with barbed wire, Colonel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly exploding) Don't talk about things you know  nothing about. He was in a  dictatorship!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dismissive) Yeah, yeah, art and politics, yeah,  yeah, I heard all about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angry) In a dictatorship, art belongs to  the Party. If you want to be a  conductor, you have to have an  orchestra. And you can only get an  orchestra if you have contact with  the power. All over the world you  need the right contacts and you  have to make the right compromises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is what I'm saying. He must  have had Party contacts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are good Party members who  help, and there are dirty non-Party  members who inform on you. Of  course, they gave him privileges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And suddenly, Steve, suddenly you  notice that they like you. They  honour you, suddenly you are the  director of the best museum in the  world, for example.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What museum?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Museum? Not... I said  orchestra. Sorry. Believe me. (another sudden  change of mood to  earnest, intimate) Help me, Steve. You say you answer  for someone from high up. I, too,  have orders from high up. Very  high up. We want FurtwГ¤ngler. I'll  give you in return the whole  orchestra, four, five conductors.  I need him, Steve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let FurtwГ¤ngler go. Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a duty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flaring) Duty? I am sorry, duty? Duty fucking  duty. Trouble is, you Americans  want everybody to live like you.  We liberated Berlin, Major Steve,  not you. Our duty also is to bring  back the best of German culture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
