dialogues.text: Dymshitz bursts out laughing. Stung, Steve advances on him, almost as if he's about to  attack him physically. He stops, sways a little, then,  after a moment, drops down in a chair near to Dymshitz.  They drink. Intimate:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna get that fucking  bandleader, Colonel. No deal. No  fucking deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you're going to kill me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drunk, Steve is clumsily, almost frantically, threading  film into the 16-mm projector. He switches off the lights then stumbles back to the  projector, turns it on and directs its beam towards a bla square of watt. It's an American military propaganda film.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll see ruins, you'll see  flowers, you'll see some mighty  pretty scenery, don't let it fool  you. You are in enemy country. The  Nazi party may be gone, but Nazi  thinking, Nazi training and Nazi  trickery remain. Somewhere in this  Germany are two million ex-Nazi  officials. Out of power but still  in there and thinking, thinking  about next time. Remember that  only yesterday every business,  every profession was part of  Hitler's system. Practically every  German was part of the Nazi network.  They believed they were born to be  masters. Don't argue with them.  You are not being sent Germany as  educators. You're a soldier on  guard. You will observe their local  laws, respect their costumes and  religion and you will respect their  property rights. You will not be  friendly. You will be aloof,  watchful and suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve, swaying slightly, watches, with the film continuin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bright summer's day. Emmi pushing her way through the  crowded market. She comes to the stall with gramophone  records. David is with her, staying behind a little so as not to  disturb her. She starts to look through the records, blowing her nose  from time to time. Then she finds a box of records, opens it, is delighted. She bargains with the stallholder, and  she hands over money.  She shows her purchase to David happily. They struggle on in the crowd. David suddenly stops. He has spotted a tand The bicycle with two seats is old and rusty but seems to  be in working order. David steps up to it, touches it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two persons, Emmi and David, riding the tandem. Emmi in  the front, pedalling, David behind. The road going up int the hills is full of potholes. They change seats. David i in the front, Emmi at the back. Suddenly the road begins  to descend. They change again, Emmi sits in the front,  David at the back. They speed down the hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tandem, ridden by Emmi and David, rolls into a huge  building, black and burnt out. In the middle of the vast hall, surrounded by the stairca there is a Christmas tree, almost burnt to cinder. Emmi  and David stare at it, mesmerised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yesterday I read that FurtwГ¤ngler  was asked to lead the New York  Philharmonic back in '36, Toscanini  suggested it. Had he accepted, he  would have become the most  celebrated conductor in America.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When he made his decision, he  couldn't have known everything.  Especially not the way people like  you do, who've returned from exile  and feel that you have a right to  pass judgement. Because you are  blameless, you think you know best  who is a sinner and who deserves  forgiveness. But you have no idea  how people lived here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When he met Hitler at his birthday  and shook hands with him, was he  pleased?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. But you and I already  know that he has saved lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve and David studying files in silence.  FurtwГ¤ngler' baton is on Steve's desk. Steve drinks black coffee. Emmi enters.  Curt nods of greeting. She goes to her desk then takes the Bruckner record to Steve. Steve looks at  the record, then glances up at Emmi. He does his best to  exclude David, who tries to hear what is said. Emmi glances at David. She's embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruckner's Seventh, Major.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know where the Adagio begins?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put it on ready to play, and I'll  tell you when to play it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He returns to his desk. Emmi looks through the album for  the appropriate record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve by the open window, looking at his wristwatch, smok a cigarette. David and Emmi both watch him.  The door ope and FurtwГ¤ngler bursts in. FURTWГ„NGLER It is now nine o'clock precisely.  I do not intend to be kept waiting  again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dangerously calm) Don't talk to me like I was a second  violinist. Go back into the waiting  room. Miss Straube will come and  get you when I am ready to see  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FurtwГ¤ngler goes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus God, who the hell does he  think he is? Who the hell does he  think he is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Emmi gaze at him as he tries to regain control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door to the landing is open and Rode is there pretend to sweep. He looks in to see FurtwГ¤ngler sitting, holdin his handkerchief over his nose and mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you perhaps like to have a  glass of water, Herr Professor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FurtwГ¤ngler doesn't seem to hear. Rode hesitates, then  continues to sweep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Emmi look at him, puzzled. She goes to the door, opens it, nods. Rode quickly  disappears.  FurtwГ¤ngler looks at Emmi. FURTWГ„NGLER What is this man doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmi doesn't answer. All eyes on the door.  FurtwГ¤ngler  enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. FurtwГ¤ngler!  Come in, come  in, sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FurtwГ¤ngler, deeply suspicious, goes for the uncomfortab chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, take this one, it's more  comfortable

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds the other chair for FurtwГ¤ngler, who sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it's too hot, open your tie. FURTWГ„NGLER (interrupting) I wish to say something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead, be my guest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FurtwГ¤ngler takes from his pocket a piece of paper with  notes. He blows his nose. The room is warming up. It will become like an airless court room, a pressure cooker. FURTWГ„NGLER When I last saw you, I was  unprepared. I did not know what to  expect. In these past weeks, I  have been thinking more carefully  and making some notes. (glances at the  notes.) You have to understand who I am  and what I am. I am a musician and  I believe in music. I am an artist  and I believe in art. Art in  general, and music, in particular,  has for me mystical powers which  nurture man's spiritual needs. I  must confess, however, to being  extremely naive.  I insisted for  many years on the absolute  separation of art and politics. My  entire life was devoted to music  because, and this is very important,  because I thought that I could,  through music, do something  practical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what was that? FURTWГ„NGLER Maintain liberty, humanity and  justice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, that's a thing of beauty,  honest to God, a real thing of  beauty. I'm going to try to remember  that. Liberty, humanity and justice.  Beautiful. But you used the word  'naive'. Are you now saying you  think you were wrong? That art and  politics can't be separated? FURTWГ„NGLER I believe art and politics should  be separate, but that they weren't  kept separate I learned to my cost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when did you first learn that -  when you sent the telegram? Was  that the surrender signal, the  waving of the white flag? FURTWГ„NGLER What telegram?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Happy birthday, dear Adolf, love  Wilhelm.' Or words to that effect.  That sounds to me like you were  dropping on your knees and saying,  'Okay, Adolf, you win. You're the  number one man. Have a swell party.' FURTWГ„NGLER I have no idea what you're talking  about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The birthday greetings you sent to  your old pal, Adolf Hider. FURTWГ„NGLER I never sent him any birthday  greetings or any other kind of  greetings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think carefully, Wilhelm... maybe  not in your own name, but as Privy  Councillor or Vice-President. FURTWГ„NGLER I don't have to think carefully.  This is utterly ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Emmi exchange the briefest of looks. David rais his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, David?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not show Dr. FurtwГ¤ngler the  evidence. It may refresh his memory? FURTWГ„NGLER You won't find it because no such  telegram exists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I tried, you got to admit I  tried. I thought I might just trap  you there, Wilhelm, but David here  was too quick for me. Smart move,  David, smart move. No, I don't  have the telegram, but I know it  exists. And I want you to know,  Wilhelm, we're going to keep looking  for it because I believe you sent  it. FURTWГ„NGLER Then you are wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Art and politics, yeah, art and  politics. Let's look at that. You  and the Berlin Philharmonic toured  the Third Reich, played in countries  the Nazis had conquered. Are you  saying that conducting in occupied  territories from 1939 on wasn't a  commercial for Adolf and all he  stood for? FURTWГ„NGLER We never, never officially  represented the regime when we  played abroad. We always performed  as a private ensemble. As I think  I already told you, I was a  freelance conductor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know something? You should've  written our insurance policies for  us because you got more exclusion  clauses than Double Indemnity.  What do you imagine people thought?  The Berlin Philharmonic's taken  over by Doctor Goebbels and his  Propaganda Ministry but Wilhelm is  a freelance, so art and politics  are now entirely separate? Is that  what you believed ordinary people  thought? FURTWГ„NGLER have no idea what ordinary people  thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! FURTWГ„NGLER No, because I had only one  intention. My only intention  whatever I did was to show that  music means more than politics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about von der Null. FURTWГ„NGLER (taken off-guard) Von der Null?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, von der Null. FURTWГ„NGLER Von der Null?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long's this going to go on,  Wilhelm? I say von der Null, you  say von der Null, I say von der  Null, you say von der Null, we  could go on all day. You know who  von der Null is, don't you? Edwin  von der Nuell, music critic. FURTWГ„NGLER Yes, I know who he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it true that because he gave  you bad reviews and praised this  young guy, Von Karajan, called him  a goddamn miracle, said he was a  better conductor than you, then  you had von der Null conscripted  into the army and no one's heard  from him since? FURTWГ„NGLER That's an outrageous lie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure you didn't call one of  your close buddies and say, God in  heaven, did you see what that guy  von der Null wrote about me? The  greatest conductor on earth. I  want him out the way. He had the  nerve to accuse me I am not playing  enough modern music. Send him to  Stalingrad. Isn't that what you  did? You don't like criticism, do  you, Wilhelm?  You surely didn't  like them saying there was another  conductor who was better than you...  Are you saying the name von der  Null was never mentioned in your  talks with Goebbels? FURTWГ„NGLER (uncomfortable) Well. Once he said he'd read what  this man wrote about me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what did he say? FURTWГ„NGLER He said, 'Don't mind him. His job  is to criticise, your job is to  conduct.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what happened to Von der Nul? FURTWГ„NGLER I have no idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've really no idea? I'll tell  you what happened. He died in  Stalingrad. FURTWГ„NGLER I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, that young conductor what's  his name? (playing with  FurtwГ¤ngler) That miracle kid, you know who I  mean. Von Karajan! But you called  him something else. C'mon. What  did you call von Karajan?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll say it, then. 'Little K.' Is  that right? You couldn't even bear  to say his name!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FurtwГ¤ngler rises angrily and starts to pace. FURTWГ„NGLER Please stop playing these games  with me. Why you should bring up  the name of another conductor is  beyond my understanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you why. You remember we  talked about you playing for  Hitler's birthday?  And you told  me that Goebbels got to your doctors  first, that you were tricked? FURTWГ„NGLER Yes, that's what happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits heavily, wipes his brow. He is sweating now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a different story to tell.  I don't think you were tricked.  Not in the way you describe. I  believe something else happened.  I've seen the Hinkel Archive, I've  seen records of phone calls, and  putting it all together, this is  what I think happened. I think  Goebbels said, 'Wilhelm, if you  won't conduct for Adolf's birthday,  we'll get the Miracle Kid, the guy  that critic, von der Null, thinks  is the greatest conductor in the  world. He's not just willing to  conduct for Adolf, he's offered to  sing "Happy Birthday" as a solo.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, admit it. K worried you,  didn't he? He always worried you.  In 1942, he's thirty-four years  old, you're already fifty-six. And  Goebbels and Goering keep saying  to you, 'If you don't do it, little  K will.' Never mind art and politics  and symbols and airy-fairy bullshit  about liberty, humanity and justice  because I don't care how great you  are. It's the oldest story in the  book, (a wry look at David) The ageing Romeo jealous of the  young buck. The real reason you  didn't leave the country when you  knew you should have was that you  were frightened that, once you  were out of the way, you'd be  supplanted by the Miracle Kid, the  Party's boy twice over, flashy,  talented little K. FURTWГ„NGLER This is absolute nonsense!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm just beginning to develop  my theme. Isn't that what you call  it in classical music, developing  your theme? Okay, so they played  on your insecurity. That's human,  understandable. But, there is one  guy who doesn't like little K as  much as he likes you - yeah, the  number one man your old pal, Adolf.  He thinks you're the greatest, and  when he says, I want Wilhelm for  my birthday, boy, they better go  out get Wilhelm. So, Josef calls  and threatens you with little K.  And you said to hell with the Ninth  in Vienna, I'll give it to Adolf  as a birthday present in Berlin.  That's the trick they played, they  got you by the balls and they  squeezed. Hard. Why did you stay?  Why did you play for them? Why  were you the flag-carrier for their  regime?  Jealousy? FURTWГ„NGLER (interrupting) Of course there was a conspiracy  against me, a campaign - even  abroad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brief silence; all eyes on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, Wilhelm, I'm talking about  ordinary, everyday reasons. Which  is why I want to discuss your  private life.  How many illegitimate  children do you have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major, I don't see how this line  of questioning could...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, what are you Counsel for  the Defence now? ( (to FurtwГ¤ngler) Did you hear the question? FURTWГ„NGLER (barely audible) I have illegitimate children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? FURTWГ„NGLER I said I have illegitimate children.  I don't know how many.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like the women, don't you,  Wilhelm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it true that before every  concert you got a woman in your  dressing room and gave her the old  conductor's baton, isn't that true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating EmmI) Major, this is deeply offensive  and repugnant!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and totally irrelevant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing to  FurtwГ¤ngler) Not so, Counsellor. That secretary  of yours, she wasn't just your  secretary, she procured women for  you, didn't she? As many and as  often as you wanted. FURTWГ„NGLER Stop this, please, stop this now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not going to stop it. Hitler  himself offered you a beautiful  house and a personal bomb shelter. FURTWГ„NGLER I absolutely refused the house and  the bomb shelter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you see what I'm getting at?  You get a gorgeous house, you're  highly paid. What are you gonna  do, stay or leave? One voice comes  back at me: stay!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major, that's not a good argument.  If Dr. FurtwГ¤ngler did indeed enjoy  all these... these privileges, he  enjoyed them because of who he is  and what he is. That's true of any  leading artist in any country in  the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it still doesn't make them  saints. They still have to get up  and piss in the middle of the night,  don't they? They can still be  vindictive and envious and mean  just like you and me. Well, just  like me. Can't they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No response. To FurtwГ¤ngler:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Wilhelm, go home now. Go  home and think about these past  twelve years. FURTWГ„NGLER I don't understand what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's your problem, Wilhelm.  You understand nothing. We'll call  you. Go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FurtwГ¤ngler leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve goes to his desk and, as FurtwГ¤ngler rises  uncertainly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your manner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My manner? Why don't you go  downstairs, get a cup of coffee  and calm down? What's the matter,  Emmi? What's going on with you?  What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry but I have to leave.  I'll find other work. You'll have  to get someone else, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this, Emmi?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do this. It's not right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's not right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have been questioned by the  Gestapo just like that. Just like  you questioned him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmi, stop! I want to show you  something. Let me show you something  and then if you want to leave, you  can leave, please please. His  friends, they did this. And he  gave them birthday concerts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he had no idea, a lot of people  had no idea. I only realised what  was really going on when I got  arrested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he had no idea, why did the  Jews need saving? This is the  question, Emmi, to all Germans:  Why did the Jews need saving in  this country? Why, if people had  no idea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would like to go now, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Steve turns on the projector and the Bergen-Belsen  film flickers into life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Band playing. Couples dancing. David and Steve at the bar each with a drink in front of them, lost in their own  thoughts. Then: Steve signs to the barkeeper to fill their glasses but  David puts a hand over his glass. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I ask you a favour, Major?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you question him again, could  you treat him with more respect?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With more what? More what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major, he may just be the greatest  conductor of this century and that  merits respect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flaring, hissing) David, I don't understand a thing  about you. You're a Jew. Are you a  Jew?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm a Jew. But I like to think  first I'm a human being.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A human being, oh, good, I'm  relieved, I thought you were going  to say you were a music lover.  This man, this great artist has  made anti-Semitic remarks like you  wouldn't believe. I got letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major, show me someone who hasn't  made an anti-Semitic remark and  I'll show you the gates of paradise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over-reacting and  overlapping) What is it with you, David? Where  are your feelings? Where's your  hatred, your disgust? Where's your  fucking outrage, David?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to go, then comes back to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think of your parents, David, and  then think of him conducting 'Happy  Birthday, dear Adolf'. I mean, for  Chrissake, whose side are you on?  Grow up! Just grow the fuck up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The customers stare at him as he stalks out. The band pla

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Emmi, sitting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to come back to the  office. May I come in? If you are  there you can influence what  happens. What good can you do by  leaving. If you go, you are giving  up and how can you help FurtwГ¤ngler  or me? Don't think about leaving.  Stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hot, Windows closed.  FurtwГ¤ngler seated. David and Emmi present.  Steve looks up from his notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody says what a great  benefactor you were to the Jews.   But-- (holds up a sheaf  of papers.) I have things here you said and  wrote. Listen to this: 'The Jew  composer Schonberg is admired by  the Jewish International.' And  what about this: 'Jewish musicians  lack a genuine affinity with our  music.' 'Jewish musicians are good  businessmen with few scruples,  lacking roots.' You deny you said  these things? FURTWГ„NGLER Those attitudes do not exist in  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe that. But just answer  the question, don't give me  explanations. FURTWГ„NGLER Speaking to Party members I used  their language, of course I did,  everyone did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with some irony) Major, sorry to interrupt, but  maybe we have to... maybe we have  to balance those things against  his assistance to his Jewish  colleagues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve tenses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a transcript of the  proceedings at Nuremberg. A Swedish businessman, Birger  Dahlerus, testified in cross- examination that he had several  meetings with Hermann Goering. 'I  first saw Goering,' Dahlerus  testified, 'embroiled in a stormy  interview with Wilhelm FurtwГ¤ngler,  the famous conductor of the Berlin  Philharmonic, who was vainly seeking  permission to keep his Jewish  concert master.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holds up his package of letters and dumps them on Emmi's  desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmi, pick one of these, any one,  read it out loud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmi is uncertain. Steve shrugs indifferently. She picks an envelope and takes out the letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) 'Please remember that Dr.  FurtwГ¤ngler risked his life to  help anyone who asked him. I  personally testify to having seen  literally hundreds of people lined  up outside his dressing room after  concerts to ask for his help. He  never turned anyone away. After he  heard me play... I am a violinist...  he gave me money because I was  unable to feed myself or my family  and then he helped me to escape to  Sweden. He helped countless people  in similar ways.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this, only one of these letters,  Major. I have lots of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) How many times have I got to tell  you I was in insurance? You think  I can't smell a phoney policy when  it's shoved under my nose? Sure,  he helped Jews, but that was just  insurance, his cover, because all  the while he was maestro of all he  surveyed, (turning on  FurtwГ¤ngler) See, Wilhelm, I think you're their  boy, their creature. You were like  an advertising slogan for them:  this is what we produce, the  greatest conductor in the world.  And you went along with it. The  truth of the matter is, Wilhelm,  you didn't need to be a member of  the Party. I made a mistake when I  asked you for your Party number. I  should've asked you for your non- Party number. Just like some other  well-known artists. (suddenly, to Emmi) Emmi, put that record on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmi puts on the record of the Adagio from Bruckner's  Seventh Symphony. After a moment:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what that is? FURTWГ„NGLER Of course I know what that is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, so what is it? FURTWГ„NGLER Bruckner's Seventh. The Adagio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's conducting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know the last time it was played  on these air waves? FURTWГ„NGLER How can I know such a thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you, then. The last time  this music was played on these air  waves was after they announced  that your pal Hitler had shot  himself. Listen to it.  They listen.   Did they pick little K's recording?  Did they pick some other conductor?  No, they picked you, and why?  Because you represented them so  beautifully. When the Devil died,  they wanted his bandleader to  conduct the funeral march. You  were everything to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music plays. FURTWГ„NGLER (near to breakdown  but struggling for  control) I have always tried to analyse  myself carefully and closely. In  staying here, I believed I walked  a tightrope between exile and the  gallows. You seem to be blaming me  for not having allowed myself to  be hanged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David takes the record off. FURTWГ„NGLER I didn't directly oppose the Party  because I told myself, that was  not my job. If I had taken any  active part in politics I could  not have remained here. But as a  musician, I am more than a citizen.  I am a citizen of this country in  that eternal sense to which the  genius of great music testifies. I  know that a single performance of  a great masterpiece was a stronger  and more vital negation of the  spirit of Buchenwald and Auschwitz  than words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An uncontrollable surge of anger wells up in Steve, causi him to pace alarmingly. He grabs the baton from his desk, stands trembling before FurtwГ¤ngler, and snaps it in hal He pushes his face close to FurtwГ¤ngler, who recoils,  terrified. David half-stands, ready to intervene physical During this Emmi puts her fingers in her ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet, terrifying) Have you ever smelled burning flesh?  I smelt it four miles away. Four  miles away, I smelt it. Have you  ever seen the gas chambers, the  crematoria? Have you seen the mounds  of rotting corpses? You talk to me  about culture, art and music? You  putting that in the scales, Wilhelm?  You setting culture, art and music  against the millions put to death  by your pals? They had orchestras  in the camps. They played Beethoven,  Wagner. The hangmen were playing  chamber music at home with their  families. I don't understand the  Germans' relationship with music.  What do you need music for? Your  pals you could call to save a few  Jews when millions of them were  being annihilated? Yes, I blame  you for not getting hanged, I blame  you for your cowardice. You strutted  and swaggered, you fucking piece  of shit, king-pin in a shithouse.  You talk to me about walking a  tightrope between exile and the  gallows, and I say to you, lies! FURTWГ„NGLER (breaking down) I love my country, I believe in  music, what was I to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look around you. See the country  you served. Look at people who had  real courage, who took risks, who  risked their lives. Like Emmi's  father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees Emmi has her fingers in her ears, yells at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmi, take your fingers out of  your ears!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She does so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm talking about your father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She screams. Stillness. All eyes on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father only joined the plot  when he realised that we could not  win the war.  She cries quietly. FURTWГ„NGLER (desperate) What kind of a world do you want,  Major? What kind of world are you  going to make? Do you honestly  believe that the only reality is  the material world, so you will be  left nothing, nothing but  feculence... more foul-smelling  than that which pervades your  nights... (near to breakdown) How was I to understand, how was I  to know what they were capable of?  No one knew. No one knew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He breaks down, buries his face in his hands, weeps. FURTWГ„NGLER I don't want to stay in this  country. Yes, I should have left  in 1934, it would have been better  if I'd left...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is suddenly overtaken by nausea and faintness, stands, a hand to his mouth. Emmi goes to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get him out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmi helps FurtwГ¤ngler out. Steve strides to the window, opens it, puts his head out into the fresh air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emmi helps FurtwГ¤ngler to a chair. She watches him  solicitously. He breathes deeply. FURTWГ„NGLER Thank you, Fraulein. You have been  most kind. (he rises.) He smiles at her. She is  embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve is trying to get a number on the telephone. David i packing up his papers. David turns to the records, starts to son through until h finds what he's looking for. He removes the Bruckner and  puts another record on the turntable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into the telephone) Major Arnold. Get me General  Wallace. General? Major Arnold,  about FurtwГ¤ngler. I don't know if  we've got a case that'll stand up,  but sure as hell we can give him a  hard time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At full volume the sound of the subdued opening of  Beethoven's Ninth Symphony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to David) Hey, turn that down, would you?  Can't you see I'm on the phone? (into the telephone) Never mind, we got a journalist  who'll do whatever we tell him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But David ignores him, sits, implacable, listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FurtwГ¤ngler walks slowly down the stairs, a broken man  struggling to regain his composure. Emmi watches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music at full blast. David, at an open window, keeps  his back to Steve, still on the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn it off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FurtwГ¤ngler, on the stairs, stops, hearing the music ech through the building. FurtwГ¤ngler left hand begins to tremble, but it is only  his way of sensing the tempo.   FurtwГ¤ngler slowly continues down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We handed Wilhelm FurtwГ¤ngler over  to the civil authorities and he  was charged with serving the Nazi  regime, with uttering anti-Semitic  slurs, performing at an official  Nazi Party function and with being  a Prussian Privy Councillor.  Dr.  FurtwГ¤ngler was acquitted. I didn't  nail him. But I sure winged him.  And I know I did the right thing.  FurtwГ¤ngler resumed his career but  he was never allowed to conduct in  the United States. He died in 1954.  Little K succeeded him as head of  the Berlin Philharmonic.
